div.head: Manuscript
div.p: MS VIII. In their “Chronological List of Poems,” the editors of the Library Edition list this poem as one of three “fragments” composed in 1831 and belonging to MS VIII, along with “I saw ye sweep athwart the deep” and “Oh mighty monarch of the noses purple red” (Ruskin, Works, 2: 537). In their separate list of the contents of MS VIII, the editors do not name this fragment, but it is presumably included within their catch‐all phrase, “and a few fragments” (Ruskin, Works, 2: 534).

div.head: Date
div.p: Approximately between August and September 1831. This poem is the first entry appearing sequentially in MS VIII, followed by “I saw ye sweep athwart the deep”. Together, the two fragments precede the first cluster of stanzas drafted for “Athens”, which was begun in about September.

The baseline for dating the entries drafted on the first two pages of MS VIII is established by the draft on p. 3 of a portion of “Iteriad,” book 4. In MS VI, this portion of draft is cross‐referenced as to be found in the “new manuscript,” which is MS VIII (see “Iteriad”: Date). That cross reference in MS VI is datable as about September 1831, and thus Ruskinʼs start on a “new manuscript” can likewise be attributed to that same period. It is possible, however, that the entries on the first two pages of MS VIII predate the “Iteriad” fragment on p. 3 by a wider margin, or even that they postdate the “Iteriad” entry—Ruskin having wrapped the first two pages of entries around the “Iteriad” fragment, with which he initiated his new notebook. While the latter possibility can be neither proven nor discounted by physical or textual evidence, it is unlikely that much time separated the works drafted in the opening three pages of MS VIII, given Ruskinʼs reference to the notebook as a “new” manuscript.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Ruskin may have drawn his idea for this poem from Byronʼs verse play, Manfred. In the heroʼs night meditation on the mountains, Manfred hopes to “linger yet with Nature” and learn “the language of another world.” Recalling when he had “stood within the Colosseumʼs wall, / ʼMidst the chief relics of almighty Rome,” Manfred is momentarily able to witness memory and nature joined by the “rolling moon” casting “a wide and tender light, / Which softenʼd down the hoar austerity / Of rugged desolation, and fillʼd up, / As ʼtwere, anew, the gaps of centuries” (Byron, Complete Poetical Works, ed. McGann, 4: 97–98 [III.iv.3, 7, 10–11, 31–35]).
